title: The Majority of Wisconsinites Support Safe and Legal Access to Abortion ...
summary: The majority of Wisconsinites (61%) support safe and legal access to abortion, as Governor Tony Evers prepares for a special legislative session on reproductive healthcare. The session aims to address the threat of Wisconsin's archaic 173-year-old abortion ban, which could be reinstated if Roe v. Wade is overturned. The ban, which provides no exceptions for cases of rape or incest, predates the Civil War and is older than the Republican Party. Governor Evers advocates for reproductive freedom and urges state legislators to listen to the public's support for abortion access and repeal the outdated law.
snippet: MADISON, Wis.  As Wisconsin legislators prepare to convene next Wednesday for Governor Tony Evers special session on reproductive healthcare, the majority of Wisconsinites  61%  support safe and legal access to abortion. title: Wisconsin law older than 20 US states - PressReader
summary: Wisconsin's 173-year-old abortion law, dating back to 1849, could be reinstated if Roe v. Wade is overturned, criminalizing abortion except to save the mother's life. Governor Tony Evers, an abortion rights supporter, highlighted that this law is older than the laws of 20 states that joined the union after 1849. These states include California, Colorado, and Hawaii. Evers' claim was verified as accurate, as 20 states were admitted after 1849, confirming that Wisconsin's abortion ban predates the laws of those states.
snippet: Wisconsins archaic abortion ban is older than 20 states, senior press secretary Kayla Anderson said in the message. ... Wade overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court, is older than 20 states. Indeed, 20 states were accepted after 1849, including California, Colorado, Washington, Alaska and Hawaii. We rate this claim True. Newspapers in English

title: Evers Campaign: Wisconsins archaic abortion ban is older than 20 states
summary: Wisconsin's abortion ban, passed in 1849, is older than 20 states, including California, Minnesota, and Oregon. Governor Tony Evers called for a special legislative session on June 22, 2022, to repeal this archaic law, which has been dormant for 50 years but could take effect if Roe v. Wade is overturned. The ban could drastically roll back abortion access in Wisconsin, returning reproductive healthcare access to a state before the Civil War. 61% of Wisconsinites support abortion access, and Evers is advocating for the Women's Health Protection Act to safeguard abortion rights
snippet: 61% of Wisconsinites support abortion access, and last month, Gov. Evers led a coalition of governors calling on Congress to pass the Womens Health Protection Act. title: A closer look at Wisconsins abortion law - WBAY
summary: Wisconsin's abortion law, originally enacted in 1849, prohibits abortions at any gestational age, with penalties including up to six years in prison and a $10,000 fine for violators. The law allows an abortion only if the mother's life is at risk, but it does not provide clear guidelines for physicians on when this exception applies. Additionally, at least two other doctors must agree for the procedure to be performed. The law does not permit abortions in cases of rape or incest. Attorney General Josh Kaul has stated he would not enforce the ban if Roe v. Wade were overturned, citing the outdated nature of the law and its incompatibility with modern medical practices. He is reviewing the Supreme Court's decision and will provide further guidance.
